results.title: Technics
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Microcosms of the Mouth”
Describes and demonstrates the development of new methods for study of the microbial masses adhering to the teeth and soft tissues in the mouth.

results.title: Merry Go-Round, Sex Education. - Part 3.
results.media_note: Sorry, we don't have images or video for this item.

results.title: Full circle
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Merry Go-Round, Sex Education. - Part 3.”.
A film for eight to ten year old children which answers the question “How does the baby begin?”. An explanation of intercourse and fertilization is given, the former using drawn silhouette figures of a man and a woman, the latter through animated drawings of sperm fertilizing the egg. The second half of the programme is about parental care.

results.title: Merry-Go-Round Sex Education. - Part 1.
results.media_note: Sorry, we don't have images or video for this item.

results.title: Beginning (TEFC)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Merry-Go-Round Sex Education. - Part 1.”.
The first in a three part series of sex-education films for young children, “Beginning” uses cross references in the animal world to explain embryonic growth and development. A microscope shows the process of cell division in the egg, and animated drawings reveal the embryo’s position in the body. Method of nourishment, and developmental changes to five months.

group_works.title: Birth. - Rev. ed.
group_works.creator_credit: Claire Chovil, BBC-TV and British Broadcasting Corporation

results.title: Birth. - Rev. ed.
results.creator_credit: Claire Chovil, BBC-TV and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Merry-go-round”.
Birth describes the steps in child delivery and the special characteristics of the new born. Simple drawings and other references to the animal world explain the general birth process, while animated illustrations showing the movement of the human embryo provide details on labour and anatomy. One sequence allows the viewer to witness the actual moment of a baby’s birth and the steps that follow. Commentary by Richard Carpenter, Melissa Docker. Animation by Barry Merritt. Suitable for upper primary and secondary levels.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Claire Chovil, BBC-TV and British Broadcasting Corporation

results.title: Merce Cunningham Dance Company = Cunningham Dance Foundation
results.brief_description: A collection of documentaries, experimental works and dance films focusing on work of legendary modern dance choreographer Merce Cunningham and his Dance Company. For additional information go to: http://www.merce.org/index.html

results.title: Variations V
results.creator_credit: Arne Arnbom and Studio Hamburg, Nordeutscher Rundfunk
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Merce Cunningham Dance Company = Cunningham Dance Foundation”.
A multi-media dance work involving twelve sound sensitive electronic poles placed around the stage performed by members of the Merce Cunningham Dance Company. The sound is triggered by the dancer’s movements and then altered or delayed by the musicians. Filmmaker Stan Van Der Beek recorded rehearsals of the dancers and then overlayed this footage as well as other stock footage images in the final film. Composer Nam June Paik projected these images on television screens during the performance. Non-dance related activities were also performed. Merce Cunningham potted a large plant and Carolyn Brown repotted it. The plant had a microphone attached to it so that any movement would produce sound. At the end of the piece, Merce Cunningham rode a bicycle through the space. Choreography by Merce Cunningham. Music by John Cage. Reference: http://www.merce.org/filmvideo.html
results.creator_credit_for_label: Arne Arnbom and Studio Hamburg, Nordeutscher Rundfunk
